title: heatwave-six-ways-cool-house---common-mistakes-avoid
story: It might be hotting up outdoors -butyoursquore stuck inside and struggling to keep cool, there are a iety of things todo to make your room cooler.Weve put together a handy heatwave guide to help.Close the curtains and windowsAlthough the first thing you might want to do on a warm and sunny day is to open the curtains and let some air in through the windows, this can sometimes make a room hotter.If the temperature is hotter outside than inside, then you could just be letting warm air in.However,you do open the windows, try to do so in a way which will encourage a through draft.Opening a lower window from the cooler side of your house and an upper window from the hotter side can help, making sure that all doors and windows are open from one end of the house to the other in order to let the air easily move through.During the night, the temperature tends to fall, soitrsquos possible, open your bedroom window a little to let a cooling breeze in as you sleep.Hanging a wet sheet in front of an open window can also help to bring the temperature in the room down.Turn the lights offLights can emit extra heat that can make your room warmer, soitrsquos not dark outside, turning them off can help to keep a room cooler.Turn electrical appliances offSimilarly to light bulbs, electrical appliances radiate heat which can make an already warm room even hotter.Unplug your phone, TV and other devices that may be radiating heat and donrsquot charge them overnightyoursquore trying to keep cool as you sleep.Use cotton or linen sheetsIf your bedroom is warm and yoursquore finding it too hot to sleep, using cotton or linen sheets can help.This is because they are breathable fabrics and better at keeping you cool than materials such as polyester.This also counts for clothes, so wearing a cotton or linen top and trouser will be cooler than heavier fabrics.If you have time when changing your sheets, you can put them in the freezer for around  minutes beforehand, so theyrsquoll feel cool when you get into bed.Make sure you place your sheets in a plastic bag before putting them in the freezer to make sure nothing spills on them and that they remain clean.FanA fan can be a good way of cooling a room down, and is a popular choice with many when the mercury rises.Placing a bowl of iced water in front of the fan can also be an extra step in keeping a room cool. This will make the air feel cool as the ice evaporates.Avoid things that can cause humidityA hot shower, the washing machine and the dishwasher all produce steam which can cause humidity and make a room feel even warmer.Use them as little as possible when a room is already too warm.

title: scotlands-schools-return-7-key-points-parents-pupils-know
story: Thousands of pupils from across Scotland will be ing to the classroom this week for the first time since March.Schools across the country are set to reopen their doors full-time from August , with some local authorities opting for blended method until August .It comes as a recent survey suggests almost half of teachers do not think it is safe for pupils to .The NASUWT union questioned  teachers ahead of schools reopening this week.The survey found teachers are anxious about going back to work and have not been given enough information or time to prepare.A total of % of those questioned do not think it will be safe for pupils to , with % uncertain.But what should parents and pupils know ahead of the t to the classroom Heres seven key points:Social distancing:There should be no requirement for physical distancing between pupils of any age.However where possible, secondary school pupils should physically distance where possible - being asked to refrain from close contact including hugs and high-fives.Pupils should not sit face-to-face at shared desks.Adults teachers will be expected to stay m from pupils other adults wherever possible.If yoursquore worried about your child going back to the classroom, National Clinical Director @JasonLeitchhas explained what schools and nurseries are doing to keep children safe and what you can expect when they get there.Find out more ## https:t.co MurxrqrqIpic sVMvVUmdash Scottish GovernmentAugust , Face coverings:PPE will not be needed in most schools, unless required by a risk assessment.Pupils will not be required to wear a face covering, but anyone wishing to do so should be allowed to.Where staff cannot maintain a m distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained period of around  minutes or more, a face covering should be worn.A changed day:Some schools and local authorities may opt for staggered start and end times to allow for less crowding as parents drop off and collect their children. Your local authority should contact you regarding this.Likewise, lunch hours and class times may be staggered to allow for less crowding in corridors and canteens.Assemblies will also be cancelled, with PE classes only taking place outdoors.School transport:Dedicated school transport should be treated as an extension of the school estate - meaningenhanced cleaning ofvehicles, and the inclusion of hand sanitising before boarding.Distancing between pupils on dedicated school transport is not required ndash but adults should remain one-metre apart from others.Pupils on school transport do not need to wear face coverings, but adults should.,params: .pushAnyone travelling to school on public transport must follow the public transport guidance on face coverings and distancing.Pupils will not need to distance on school busesHygiene:A ldquorigorous approach to environment cleaning must be implemented to prevent the virus from spreading, according to the Scottish Government.This means pupils may not be allowed to bring in as many belongings as before.Enhanced hygiene measures must be practised, including:Extra time for pupils and staff to clean their hands with soap and warm running water or sanitiser when: they arrive at school,from breaks, change rooms and before and after eating.Provision of adequate hand-washing or sanitising facilities throughout the school estate.Arrangements to support young children and those with complex needs who may need assistance.Coronavirus testing:The Scottish Government says arrangements are in place to monitor developments and allow for a ldquorapid response to any cases of the virus.They say this includes ldquoenhanced surveillance arrangements, test and protect and outbreak management.Contingency plans:In the event of a national or local outbreak, schools may need to introduce their plans for blended learning or close temporarily to help control transmission.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government websitehere.

title: sqa-exams-u-turn---know-far-john-swinney-might-change
story: EDUCATION secretary John Swinney is to address anger over the exam results ldquoscandal in Scotland as he faces calls to resign over the saga.The Deputy First Minister is to set out a series of seps to address concerns on Tuesday, amid mounting criticism over the downgrading of pupilsrsquo results.But what is the anger all about  And what has John Swinney said about a potential U-turn Here, we detail out everything you need to know about the SQA exam results saga:Why are people annoyed With no exams sat this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, the Scottish Qualications Authority applied a methodology that saw grades estimated by teachers downgraded.Pass rates for pupils in the most deprived data zones were reduced by .% in comparison with .% for pupils from the most affluent backgrounds.Exams were unable to go ahead this yearWhat is the Scottish Government doing about it Education Secretary John Swinney is expect to perform a major U-turn in a bid to sort out the current situation.The Courier reports that Mr Swinney is set to announce changes to the grades appeals process for pupils, with officials said to be examining ways to automatically review the results of downgraded pupils without each having to lodge an inidual appeal.On #SQAResultsI have heard the anger of students who feel their hard work has been taken away from them and I am determined to address it.These are unprecedented times and as we have said throughout this pandemic, we will not get everything right first time.mdash John SwinneyAugust , In a statement released on Sunday, Mr Swinney said: ldquoI have heard the anger of students who feel their hard work has been taken away from them and I am determined to address it.ldquoThese are unprecedented times and as we have said throughout this pandemic, we will not get everything right first time."Every student deserves a grade that reflects the work they have done, and that is what I want to achieve.ldquoI have been engaged in detailed discussions over the way forward and I know that we need to act and act quickly to give certainty to our young people.ldquoI will set out on Tuesday how we intend to achieve that.How have pupils reacted to the results Across the country pupils took to protest the results both in person and through an online petition.So far nearly , people have signed the petition, which hit out at what it called a ldquoclassist marking scheme.More than , people have signed a petitionPetition founder Sarah McLauchlan said: ldquoResults should be based off personal performance and personal performance only.ldquoEvery child is dferent, so assuming just because they are from a deprived area they wonrsquot do as well and children from privileged areas will excel is biased and unfair.ldquoIt is completely unacceptable and wrong, especially when class should not be a basis for results which impact the rest of a childrsquos le.The petition can be found here.What have political opponents said Scottish Labour will this week table a motion of no confidence in Mr Swinney, who is also the Deputy First Minister, which will be supported by the Scottish Conservatives.Earlier, Lord McConnell, the former Labour first minister, issued a warning to Nicola Sturgeon and John Swinney over the exam results chaos, saying ldquoget it fixed or go.Lord McConnell said the fiasco which saw , pupilsrsquo results downgraded is ldquonot good enough for Scotland.And writing in the Sunday Times, former SNP minister Alex Neil said the Scottish Government ldquomust reverse the decisions it made about examination results that saw the poorest children in many of the most deprived areas downgraded on the altar of a manufactured algorithm prepared in secret.A Scottish Government spokesman said about three-quarters ndash , ndash of all grade estimates required no adjustment, adding that the SQA results ldquoshow a narrowing of the gap between the most and least disadvantaged young people attaining grades AndashC compared to last year, and to a level below the average for the last four years.Pupils protesting the exams scandalScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said First Minister Nicola Sturgeon must remove Mr Swinney, saying she either ldquobacks Scotlandrsquos pupils or she backs an education secretary that has presided over this exams fiasco.,params: .pushScottish Labourrsquos education spokesman, Iain Gray, said Mr Swinney ldquoneeds to go, adding: ldquoItrsquos taken John Swinney five days to even admit this fiasco is his responsibility. The threat of a no-confidence motion has seen him finally accept the fact that he got this badly wrong.The Scottish Greens and Liberal Democrats have not saidthey will back the no-confidence motion.Scottish Greens education spokesman Ross Greer said he welcomed John Swinneyrsquos ldquoadmission that the Scottish Government got this badly wrong.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoAn admission of error is step one in resolving this major issue but the detailed solution is what matters.ldquoWhy we ever got into this sorry state is a question that needs answered too.

title: borders-book-festival-jonathon-porritt-talks-climate-change
story: THIS Sundaysees environmentalist and writer Jonathon Porritt joining the Borders Book Festivals online audience to talk about his latest book, Hope In Hell: A Decade To Confront The Climate Emergency.Porritt, , is one of the UKs leading environmental activists, whose roles have included chair of The Ecology Party , director of Friends of the Earth, and co-founder of Forum for the Future, a sustainable development charity.Author of nine other books, Porritt hopes his latestwill reach "a combination of dferent audiences", the most important of which, he says, is the young people who are inheriting the impacts of manmade climate change."My sense today is that young people are the ones who are really going to suffer most from the accelerating climate impacts that we are now witnessing," Porritt tells the Border , "and every single day for the whole of the rest of their lives will in one way or another be impacted by climate change."He adds: "I talk a lot in the book about what I call intergenerational injustice how one generation has basically made it practically impossible for the next generation to have the same prospects, the same expectations, the same hopes as previous generations have had."The book, which stresses the urgency of fighting climate change, is also aimed at the "weary environmentalists" who have "been plugging away" at campaigning and those, says Porritt, "who have no pre-existing knowledge or deep understanding of climate change, who I hope will be able to get stuck in really quickly and pick up everything they need to know within the first four chapters."Porritt has little time for the idea that human activity might not have had an impact on climate change, or that the subject is over-egged by the media or environmental activists.He says: "I dont believe there is any serious continuing debate about whether climate change is happening or whether its caused by our lestyles or our economy and I think theres less and less of a debate about it not being serious."I think thats symptomatic of a change going on in peoples minds because they can see the impacts of climate change."The veteran campaigner believes that any failure of iniduals to change their behaviour is not down to climate change denial but what he calls "disavowal" ndash "As in, I see this is happening but perhaps Im not the person who can make a dference, so I will continue to be a bystander rather than an active participant in addressing this challengersquo," says Porritt."The story of the next decade is getting more and more people to come away from that bystander role and to be prepared to get stuck in."And Porritt believes this "disavowal" is part of the reason governments can be slow to enact policies to combat climate change."Thats what makes it possible for the politicians to go on downgrading the signicance of climate change," he says.ldquoOur politicians are not in denial but they are absolutely not addressing it as the emergency that the science now tells us it is."And you can see that in the policies they brought forward in response to the pandemic ndash the build back better movement has actually just become build build build."The UK governments "classic failure of deeper political understanding" is one reason the countrys economy struggled during lockdown, believes Porritt.He says: "Instead of using this as a fantastic opportunity to show how we could have an economy that is prosperous but very low carbon all were doing is defaulting to exactly the same kind of policy growth band positions that we were in before COVID."Having had this shock, this really traumatic impact on our expectations of what a good le looks like, its incumbent on us to learn that lesson, and use it to help shape a more resilient and compassionate economy, one that is more mindful of environmental stewardship obligations for ourselves as well as future generations."And it is the future generations who Porritt sees pushing for change.He says: "It was so interesting when Greta Thunberg was here in the UK. I think it was Michael Gove who said, Your example gives us hope. And she instantly responded and said, We dont want your hope, we want clear, cost-effective but very radical policy responses to the climate change. We dont want you to be hopeful on our behalf, we want you to be active on our behalfrsquo.He concludes: "Would you not be annoyedyou were a young person who was suddenly confronted by the reality of climate change ldquoOnly to hear politicians say, Well, its dficult to address this, I think this is a challenge for future generations."It makes me feel pretty mad even at the advanced age of , when I hear politicians talking like that ndash its so complacent, its so self-indulgent, its so contemptuous of the interests of young people today."To see in Jonathon Porritt in conversation with journalist and broadcaster Sheena McDonald, go to bordersbookfestival.org online-event jonathon-porritt-hope-in-hellThe Borders Book Festival is sponsored by Baillie Gford.

title: craig-lowrie-completes-fundraiser-memory-late-sister
story: GALASHIELS man Craig Lowrie has completed his fundraising challenge ndash and he says the donations total is ldquounbelievable.Mr Lowrie has now run a dozen km runs during the Border summer festival season, having completed his final event in Coldstream on Friday ."It was always going to be an emotional run as it was the last one," said Mr Lowrie, of Selkirk, whose son Robbie was last yearrsquos Braw Lad in Galashiels.The challenge was created after this yearrsquos festivals were cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.Around pound, has been raised, according to Mr Lowrie, with the money going to the festival committees, as well as the Borders General Hospital.However, Mr Lowrie dedicated his efforts to his late sister, Donna Cameron, of Innerleithen, who died in a road collision last year, just two weeks before her nephews appearance as Braw Lad.Following the completion of the runs, Mr Lowrie said: "It was good to get them finished ndash the running was the easy bit.Reflecting on Fridayrsquos event, he added: "My sisters kids and husband were coming down, and apart from Innerleithen they had not been to any of the other runs."Mr Lowrie was due to be joined by his son in Coldstream, but Robbie had an injury which left him on crutches.But Mr Lowrie didnt run his last challenge alone ndash former Selkirk Standard Bearer Rory Monks joined in."Rory stepped forward to run with me," said Mr Lowrie. "I was glad to have the company as on my own it would have been gruelling."At the time of going to print, Mr Lowrie estimated that his fundraiser had reached a total of around pound, - with just over pound, being raised through his online Go Fund Me page."Its phenomenal, said Mr Lowrie. "I sat with Robbie at the beginning of the summer to talk about it."I didnt expect anything near what weve done ndash its unbelievable."Once he had completed his mammoth task, racking up more  kilometres across the summer, Mr Lowrie gave a speech to supporters through a Facebook livestream.In his speech, Mr Lowrie said: "Especially in these uncertain times we live in, you made the dference ndash I only ran."The comments you guys have posted each week ndash some heartfelt, some really encouraging, some quite funny ndash all really did mean a lot to me and gave me a great sense of pride."To support Craig Lowries fundraiser, visit his Go Fund Me page.

title: galashiels-pavilion-cinema-reveals-date-reopening
story: THE Pavilion Cinema in Galashiels will reopen to the public next week.The Market Street venue has been closed for the last five months due to the coronavirus pandemic.But film lovers will be able tonext Friday .Cinema manager Andrew Poole said: ldquoThe past few months have been the longest and hardest in our familyrsquos  years in running cinemas."But we have survived and we are ready to reopen, albeit under extraordinarily dficult conditions."When we reopen, we will have a range of measures in place to protect our customers including fewer performances to allow deeper cleaning of halls between shows, one-way systems at the concessions stand, perspex screens, hand sanitiser stations throughout the building and we will be adhering to the physical distancing rules in place at that time."We are able to ensure our customers are sat two metres apart in the cinema hall using our booking system."All customers are encouraged to book in advance, but tickets will be available at the cinema."Classic films will be shown at first, before Christopher Nolans Tenetis screened on August .Mr Poole added: "Films such as Peter Rabbit, Jumanji, The Greatest Showmanand Harry Potterwill play alongside Disneyrsquos Onwardwhich had only been showing for a week before we closed."We will also be showing Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back, currently celebrating its th anniversary."We havenrsquot been idle during lockdown. Wersquove carried out some refurbishment works including some repainting, and wersquove also just completed our pound, audio replacement project, replacing our entire audio system including sound processors, ampliers and speakers, upgrading to Dolby . surround sound."And wersquove installed the Dolby Fidelio system to improve access to film for customers who are hard of hearing or visually impaired."The cinema is also launching a Movie Party hall hire scheme, where groups of up to  can enjoy a film privately.Mr Poole said: "After five months of watching films on living room TVs, wersquore confident that our customers will be desperate to get out the house and see films on the big screen once again. Films are made to be watched in cinemas."And with the safety measures we will have in place, we think our customers will feel safe enjoying films where they are best viewed."

title: melrose-rugby-coaches-complete-41-mile-fundraiser
story: MELROSE rugby coaches completed a -mile exercise challenge at the weekend.Bruce Ruthven, Nicholas Alston and Blair Roden travelled from Moffat to Melrose on Saturdayby running, swimming, kayaking and cycling.The trio collected more than pound, for the Move With Mark fundraiser, launched in June by Lachlan Gaddie and his sister Hannahafter their father Mark was diagnosed with cancer.ldquoWersquore really delighted with how the whole day went, said Ruthven, Melrose RFCrsquos head coach.The Move With Mark challenge has now generated more than pound,, with donations going to the Borders General Hospitaland the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh.Car salesman Mark Gaddie, of Melrose, has been receiving treatment at the Edinburgh hospital five times a week. It comes a decade on from his wersquos death from cancer in the BGH.As part of the Move With Mark challenge, Lachlan and Hannah have each been covering . miles every day ndash and they have encouraged others to cover the same distance by swimming, running, cycling or rowing.Yet on Saturday, Ruthven, Alstonand Rodenstepped up to the plate and decided to set themselves the task of covering  miles.Beginning at Moffat Rugby Clubrsquos ground at am, they ran  miles to St Maryrsquos Loch.They then completed a one-mile kayak, followed by a -metre open swim and, lastly, a -mile cycle to Melrose via Selkirk and Abbotsford.ldquoWe had the run finished by .am, so we had probably the toughest part of the day out the way by lunchtime and then the rest of the day was really quite pleasant, said Ruthven, who lives in Peebles.The journey went by without a hitch, according to Ruthven, who expressed gratitude to the grouprsquos -strong ldquosupport team, as well as the dozens of well-wishers lining the route.ldquoThere must have been close to  people throughout the day following us, which really helped, said Ruthven.ldquoTheyrsquore quite winding and twisting roads but we had no issues whatsoever ndash it went really smoothly.He added: ldquoWe managed to complete the  miles in about six hours, which was the time we were aiming for.Ruthven said he came up with the challenge because of his desire to help Hannah and Lachlan. Lachlan plays rugby for Melrose.ldquoIt was really just to support Hannah and Lachlan who are going through a challenging and dficult time, said Ruthven.ldquoThe whole club got behind the challenge and Irsquod like to think thatrsquos a sign of things to come for Melrose Rugby Club. The support we had was overwhelming at times.To donate to the fundraising site set up by Ruthven, Alston and Roden, you can visit the lsquoMoffat to Melrosersquo page on JustGiving

title: eat-help-scotland---interactive-map-shows-50-discount-near
story: AN interactive map has been created to easily show the restaurants in your area offering a % discount.UntilAugust ,onMondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, restaurantsparticipating in the UK Governments Eat Out to Help Out scheme will offer half pricefoodand non-alcoholic drinks up to a total value of pound per person.Alcoholic drinks and service charges are excluded from the offer.Restaurants are offering % off foodThe initiative, launched by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, is encouraging peopleto support the hospitality industry by getting back to having meals out ascoronaviruslockdown measures are eased.In the first week more than  million meals were purchased as part of the new initiative.The Treasury said it had been sent ,, claims for inidual meals from restaurants as part of the Eat Out to Help Out programme.The interactive map showing locations within an area of GlasgowIt means that a maximum of pound. million can have been claimed in the first week of the scheme, which runs on every Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in August.The Treasury has put aside pound million to pay for the programme.The around , restaurants that have signed up to the Eat Out scheme so far take off % of a customerrsquos bill at the till and are reimbursed by the Treasury.How does it work You donrsquot need a voucher to use the scheme and you can use it at the same time as other offers and discounts. There is no minimum spend.Establishments will then claim a reimbursement from the UK Government for the discount theyrsquove given you.Who is taking part in the scheme Among the big-name chains taking part in the scheme are McDonalds, Nandos, Burger King, Costa Coffee, Frankie  Bennys, Harvester and KFC.But countless numbers of local establishments are also taking full advantage.The UK Government has created a portal where people can find out which restaurantsare registered with Eat Out to Help Out.The map covers all areas of ScotlandHow to find locations near me A handy interative map has been set up to make the process easy for customers.All you have to do is enter your postcode into the Eat To Help website here, and the list is shown in front of you.Simple!

title: scotlands-schools-return-four-simple-tips-help-young-people-sleep
story: A charity has outlined four simple tips to help children and young people get to sleep now they have ed to school.For thousands of people across the country, this week marks their first time in a classroom since March.And with the pressures of ing to school and the drastic change from lockdown le, many might find it hard to fall asleep.Sleep Scotland, a charity organisation working to address sleep issues in children and young people, says that lockdown has resulted in youngsters experiencing poor sleep.Schools are back in Scotland this weekldquoThere are many factors affecting sleep but a crucial one is our Circadian rhythms, they said.ldquoOur circadian rhythms are the physical, mental and behavioural changes that follow a daily cycle.ldquoNearly every cell and tissue has its own rhythm, controlled by our biological clocks.ldquoIf our biological clocks are disrupted it can affect our circadian rhythms, and these changes have been linked to lots of other issues, including over activity, depression and obesity.They have set out four important factors for parents to pay attention to, in order to get your childrsquos sleep back on track for theto school.The four tips:Light#According to Sleep Scotland exposure to light at the wrong time can sht sleep and wakefulness - causing your brain to be alert.Their guidance says: "Make sure your room at bedtime is dark. Reduce light from the hall. Make sure there are no electronics sending out light e.g. a digital alarm clock with a lit display, sleep buttons on equipment etc."You may want to put black curtains at the window or wear an eye mask to limit the light getting into the eye."Sleep Scotland suggests wearing an eye maskOn the other end, you should also get lots of light in the morning to help you feel awake and alert.They added: "Exposure to light at the right time helps keep the circadian clock on the correct time schedule."Make sure you open the curtains and turn on the lightsyou need to. Going for a walk is a great way to start the day."RoutineIt is only natural that during lockdown many of us have found that we have lost our routine and have been staying up later and lying in bed longer in the morning.Sleep Scotland said: "Your body clock works best when you stick to a schedule."In an ideal world, yoursquoll go to sleep and wake up within a half hour of the same time each day, even on weekends."The routines of the day also give us powerful signals and demands that the body remain alert for certain tasks and events."Regular waking and bed times, alongside regular meal times are very important for regulating your body and its s."Sleep PressureSleep pressure is the term used to describe the feeling of tiredness we have, due to the activity we undertake through the day.,params: .pushSleep Scotland say it is important to be active in order to make sure we create the sleep pressure and drowsiness that will help us to fall asleep.They argue that having a nap can relieve our sleep pressure, meaning we find it harder to fall asleep at bedtime.Take a tech breakNaturally during lockdown many of us have resorted to using screens to help keep us entertained,to work and to socialise with friends.And while most modern tech has a blue light filter, it does not filter all light.More importantly, the things you do online are usually things that stimulate your brain and make it harder to turn off when you get into bed.Therefore, Sleep Scotland say you should unplug from all screens at least an hour before bedtime.They added: "In the hour before bed, ensure you focus on doing things that are calming."Now is the time to read, draw, do some calming exercises, have a warm bath etchellip"

title: selkirk-needs-20mph-speed-limit
story: A MPH speed limit should be introduced in Selkirk, according to some community councillors.During a video-conference meeting on Monday , Selkirk Community Council members discussed ways to reduce speeding in the town.David Deacon said: "We need to do something, rather than just talking."Treasurer Judith Thompson expressed interest in Selkirk becoming a ldquorsquos Plenty town.The national campaign, s Plenty For Us, aims to reduce speeds in residential and urban streets to mph.Community council secretary Kirsty Lovatt explained that she had previously been part of a similar campaign.She said she hoped s Plenty would be introduced in the town as it has "so many built up areas".Ms Lovatt also revealed that when she had previously begun the process of introducing the traffic measure, she was advised that it was unlikely to be possible in Selkirk.She said: "I was told it was too expensive to introduce new signage."During Mondayrsquos meeting, members all appeared to agree with the sentiment that there is a speeding issue in the town.And Scottish Borders Council representative Caroline Cochrane, who represents Selkirkshire, said: "Fleece Corner [A] is always a bad one [for speeding]."It was then proposed by Ms Cochrane that a stall be included in the next Selkirk Farmers Market, to be held on September , to gauge interest in supporting the move to a mph zone throughout the town.The community council agreed to work on the creation of a town petition ready for public viewing.

title: john-swinneys-sqa-u-turn-seven-things-need-know
story: John Swinney has announced today that the Scottish Governmentwill abandon the downgrade of more than , exams, with original teacher estimates insteadbeing used to determine this yearrsquos results.The Education Secretary announced the U-turn after a backlash from students who felt they had been treated unfairly by the Scottish Qualications Authoritywhen it recalculated their results.John Swinney said he knew that the apology was not enough, and action would need to be taken to recty the situation.Here are seven things you need to know from his announcement:Teachers estimates to be restored:All downgraded marks will be restored and new certicates sent out.Mr Swinney said: ldquoUsing powers available to me in the EducationAct , I am today directing the SQA to re-issue those awards based solely on teacher or lecturer judgment.ldquoSchools will be able to confirm the estimates they provided for pupils to those that are ing to school this week and next.ldquoThe SQA will issue fresh certicates to affected candidates as soon as possible and, importantly, will inform Ucas and other admission bodies of the new grades as soon as practical in the coming days to allow for applications to college and university to be progressed.What are the new Scottish results The A to C attainment rates for National , Higher and Advanced Higher are now expected to jump by ., . and . percentage points compared to , rising to .%, .% and .% respectively.Will any grades be lowered The Education Secretary has said that no grades which were moderated to give an increased mark will be reduced.When will the results be given John Swinney said that schools will be able to confirm the estimates they provided for pupils to those that are ing to school this week and next.He added: "The SQA will issue fresh certicates to affected candidates as soon as possible and, importantly, will inform UCAS and other admission bodies of the new grades as soon as practical in the coming days to allow for applications to college and university to be progressed.Will all students get into their course Mr Swinney has said that due to the unique circumstances of this situation the Scottish Government ldquowill make provision for enough places in universities and colleges to ensure that no-one is crowded out of a place they would otherwise have been awarded."WhatI have already appealed Pupils, who had been encouraged to appeal their downgrades, will get their new results automatically, although appeals will still be possibledesired.What will lessons from the process of awarding qualications this year that will help to inform any future actions."He also said that an investigation will be undertaken to look at how this yearrsquos awards were handed out.He said: ldquoCoronavirus has not gone away and, while we expect next yearrsquos exams to go ahead, we need to put in place the right plans to make sure we donrsquot find ourselves in the same situation again.Mr Swinney announced that a ldquorapid consultation exercise with teachers will start this week, looking at removing parts of course assessment and adjusting the volume of title: covid-generation-students-urged-join-nursing-workforce
story: A-level students are being encouraged to consider a career in nursing.Pupils going through clearing should apply to study the profession, chief nursing officer for England Ruth May said.The NHS in England said the so called ldquoCovid generation should not just clap for carers, they should become one.It said that interest in nursing is already high ndash with surges seen in Ucas applications attributed to the ldquoleading role nurses have played in the fight against the Covid- pandemic.vw,vw,px, px"Chief nursing officer for England Ruth May The health service said there are ldquono shortage of jobs for people after they have qualied.It said that pupils going through clearing on Thursday should search for ldquonursing careers online.Ms May said: ldquoThe last six months has seen nurses and midwives play a leading role in the fight against coronavirus, cementing the high esteem they are held in by the nation, so itrsquos no surprise that interest in nursing degrees is already high.ldquoUncertain times lay ahead, but one thing we can be sure of is that the country and the NHS will always need nurses, and that nursing will always offer a rewarding and ied career ndash making it a strong choice for any young people considering their options tomorrow.Commenting on the rallying call, Mike Adams,director for England at the Royal College of Nursing, said: ldquoThis is a welcome step, when there are very large numbers of unfilled nurse jobs and the government needs to do everything it can to get the next generation through the door.ldquoNursing is a wonderfully rewarding career but we need to see more done to attract the nurses of the future..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title:  uCovid generation u students urged to join nursing workforce

title: new-species-dinosaur-discovered-isle-wight
story: Four bones found on the Isle of Wight belong to a new species of dinosaur from the same family as Tyrannosaurus rex, scientists say.Palaeontologists from the University of Southampton say the creature lived in the Cretaceous period  million years ago and is estimated to have been up to four metres long.The dinosaur ndash which is a new species of theropod dinosaur, the group that includes Tyrannosaurus rex and modern-day birds ndash has been named Vectaerovenator inopinatus.The name refers to the large air spaces in some of the bones, one of the traits that helped the scientists identy its theropod origins.These air sacs, also seen in modern birds, were extensions of the lungs.It is likely they helped fuel an efficient breathing system while also making the skeleton lighter.The bones, discovered on the foreshore at Shanklin last year, are from the neck, back and tail.vw,vw,px, px"Still images of the vertebrae The fossils were found over a period of weeks in  in three separate discoveries ndashtwo by iniduals and one by a family group, who all handed in their finds to the nearby Dinosaur Isle Museum at Sandown.Scientic study has confirmed the fossils are very likely to be from the same inidual dinosaur, with the exact location and timing of the finds adding to this belief.Robin Ward, a regular fossil hunter from Stratford-upon-Avon, was with his family visiting the Isle of Wight when they made their discovery.He said: ldquoThe joy of finding the bones we discovered was absolutely fantastic. I thought they were special and so took them along when we visited Dinosaur Isle Museum.ldquoThey immediately knew these were something rare and askedwe could donate them to the museum to be fully researched.James Lockyer, from Spalding, Lincolnshire was also visiting the island when he found another of the bones.He said: ldquoIt looked dferent from marine reptile vertebrae I have come across in the past.ldquoI was searching a spot at Shanklin and had been told and read that I wouldnrsquot find much there.ldquoHowever, I always make sure I search the areas others do not, and on this occasion it paid off.After studying the four vertebrae, palaeontologists from the University of Southampton confirmed that the bones are likely to belong to a genus of dinosaur previously unknown to science.Their findings will be published in the journal Papers In Palaeontology.Chris Barker, a PhD student at the university who led the study, said: ldquoWe were struck by just how hollow this animal was ndash itrsquos riddled with air spaces.ldquoParts of its skeleton must have been rather delicate.ldquoThe record of theropod dinosaurs from the lsquomidrsquo Cretaceous period in Europe isnrsquot that great, so itrsquos been really exciting to be able to increase our understanding of the ersity of dinosaur species from this time.ldquoYou donrsquot usually find dinosaurs in the deposits at Shanklin as they were laid down in a marine habitat.ldquoYoursquore much more likely to find fossil oysters or drtwood, so this is a rare find indeed.Scientists say that it is likely the Vectaerovenator lived in an area just north of where its remains were found, with the carcass having washed out into the shallow sea nearby..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: New species of dinosaur discovered on the Isle of Wight

title: a-level-students-can-use-grades-mock-exams-progress-degree-courses
story: GCSE and A-level students in England will be able to use grades in mock exams to progress to university and college courses and employment, the Education Secretary has announced.Results in mock tests ndash which were held before schools were forced to close amid the Covid- crisis ndash will carry the same weight as the calculated results to be awarded this month, Gavin Williamson said.The move, described by one union leader as ldquopanicked and chaotic, comes after unions called on the UK Government to follow Scotlandrsquos lead in scrapping moderated grades as the downgrading of more than , results was reversed.In a U-turn announced on Tuesday, Scotlandrsquos Education Secretary John Swinney revealed that downgraded results would revert to the grades estimated by pupilsrsquo teachers.It comes after this yearrsquos summer exams were cancelled amid Covid-. Teachers were told to submit the grades they thought each student would have receivedthey had sat the papers.Exam boards have moderated these grades to ensure this yearrsquos results ndash for students in England, Northern Ireland and Wales ndash are not signicantly higher than previous years.But now students in England awaiting their A-level and GCSE results can keep their grades in mock examsthey are higher than the calculated grade, with regulator Ofqual asked to determine how and when valid mock results can be used.Students will have to go through the appeals process to use their mock exam result, with their school required to submit evidence to the exam board.And they will still be able to sit exams in the autumnthey are unhappy with the grades they secured in mock exams, orthey are dissatisfied with results awarded by exam boards on Thursday.All three grades will hold the same value with universities, colleges and employers, the Department for Educationsaid.vw,vw,px, px"Secretary of State for Education Gavin Williamson Mr Williamson also announced an additional pound million in funding to help schools and colleges carry out the autumn exam series for students wishing to sit GCSE and A-level exams.But the appeals process ndash where inidual students in England are dependent on schools and colleges to appeal against results on their behalf ndash is expected to remain the same.Mr Williamson said: ldquoEvery young person waiting for their results wants to know they have been treated fairly.ldquoBy ensuring students have the safety net of their mock results, as well as the chance of sitting autumn exams, we are creating a triple lock process to ensure they can have the confidence to take the next step forward in work or education.Geoff Barton, General Secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said the plan created potential for ldquomassive inconsistency as mock exams were not standardised and some students may not have taken them before schools closed in March.He said: ldquoThe idea of introducing at the eleventh hour a system in which mock exam results trump calculated grades beggars belief. The government doesnrsquot appear to understand how mock exams work. They arenrsquot a set of exams which all conform to the same standards. The clue is in the name lsquomockrsquo.ldquoSchools and colleges have spent months diligently following detailed guidance to produce centre-assessed grades only to find they might as well not have bothered.ldquoIf the government wanted to change the system it should have spent at least a few days discussing the options rather than rushing out a panicked and chaotic response.vw,vw,px, px"Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer: lsquoI would urge the Prime Minister to change course, or he risks robbing a generation of their futurersquo Labour has urged the Government to carry out urgent changes, including helping students to correct their grades with credible appeals and resits and clarying which students are likely to be worst affected by the model being used.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: ldquoWith  hours before results are released, I would urge the Prime Minister to change course, or he risks robbing a generation of their future.Lord Baker, who served as an education secretary under Margaret Thatcher, said it appeared Scotland had ldquogot it right and those that will suffer from downgrading are most likely to be the brightest students in the poorest schools.He told the : ldquoScotland makes it exceptionally dficult for the Prime Minister. Itrsquos egg on face, there is no question about that.There are also fears mid-ranking A-level students could face a grading ldquolottery after they were put in rank order against their classmates within each grade for each subject, according to Professor Alan Smithers, director of the Centre for Education and Employment Research at the University of Buckingham..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: A-level students can use grades in mock exams to progress to degree courses

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: covid-19-recovery-queen-margaret-universitys-new-plan
story: Professionals educated in many of its key areas, from health sciences to the creative arts and social sciences, have already played key roles in tackling the pandemic.As the university launched its new Strategic Plan, which outlined its goals for the next five years, it was stressed that they would also be ldquovital to the global recovery.Highlighted were the graduates and staff who could already be found in positions all across the world, influencing policy, and enhancing society, culture and the economy. The university aimed to continue ldquoto make a real and immediate dference in the world, in keeping with its values.The strategy described how the university would contribute to societyrsquos ldquorecovery and recalibration following the coronavirus pandemic.It also set out how QMUrsquos ldquoperson-centred approach to learning made it ldquostand out from other universities, along with its ldquodistinctive academic portfolio and a focus on making society better.Through teaching, research and innovation, the university would further develop its work enabling people to ldquoheal, nurture, care and communicate, as well as inspire them to build and rebuild businesses, find solutions to real-le issues and to support communities. It would also build on its track record fostering creativity and artistic expression, building social and economic capital in the process.Sir Paul Grice, principal and vice-chancellor, said: ldquoOur new strategy holds true to the ethos of social justice on which this institution was founded. It sets out how we will nurture and build on our vital work improving society through teaching, research and innovation.

title: love-first-sight-couple-toast-golden-anniversary
story: Norman and Sophia Taylor enjoyed a socially distanced golden wedding anniversary, due to the Covid- restrictions, at their home on North Grange Avenue on July  with their three children.Northumbrian-born Norman, who turned  on June , met Sophia, , in Prestonpans Royal British Legion in , saying it was ldquolove at first sight and ldquoeyes over a dance floor.The pair married shortly afterwards at Prestonpans Register Office and then went on to travel the world due to Normanrsquos job as a fitter and turner, a trade he learned in the Merchant Navy.The family travelled across Britain between  and . They then stayed in Africa between  and , including Zambia, with the children attending public school in South Africa.However, Sophia started to feel homesick so moved back to Prestonpans in .Norman then got a job in Libya, working four weeks away and then being back at home for four weeks. He worked in this job for the rest of his career, retiring  years ago.During his working le, Norman was also a delivery driver.However, after his retirement he took on the role as a golf caddy at Muirfield, near Gullane.Prestonpans-born Sophia, as Cissie to her friends, worked as a barmaid, including at the former Lady Susan pub in Prestonpans.When Norman married Sophia, she had three children from a previous marriage: Richard, now aged , Charles, , and Eileen, .Their grandson Kal, described as the ldquoapple of their eye, was born in  and was ldquospoiled rotten according to Sophia.Norman and Sophia have sadly been in poor health recently, with Norman suffering a heart attack this year.However, he still makes an effort to visit the Legion in Prestonpans twice a week, every Monday and Friday.When the Legionrsquos beer garden re-opened and Norman was able to go back to his favourite bar, Richard said it was ldquothe first time I have seen a smile on his face for months.Norman says the secret to a long marriage is ldquothe we is always right.Richard added: ldquoThey are totally in love. Irsquove never seen my mum and dad fight and my dad has never risen his voice once. My dad is an absolute gentleman and they absolutely dote on each other.

title: ufo-special-seven-strangest-unexplained-sightings-scotlands-skies
story: Three declassied videos newly released by the Pentagon showing US Navy pilots encountering "unidentied aerial phenomena" ndash or what the rest of us might call UFOs ndash has helped stoke further intrigue about what mysterious objects may be traversing our skies.Theres been a flurry of unexplained sightings reported around the globe ndash in recent months Belgium has recorded its highest number since the countrys famed "UFO wave"  years ago.Scotland is no stranger to a stellar UFO story either. In May, an Airdrie supermarket worker took photographs that he claimed showed a strange blueish-green "flying saucer" and a diamond-shaped cluster of "neon beams" while walking home from work.Here, we look atsome of our favourite tales of strange sightings in the sky.Seven of Scotlands strangest UFO sightings:West Lothian: A close encounterForestry worker Robert Taylor, below, found himself at the heart of one of Scotlands most famous UFO mysteries when he stumbled across a "a huge flying dome" in a woodland clearing near Dechmont Law in Livingston on November , .As he approached the hovering object, two spheres, each about three feet wide with protruding metal spikes "similar to sea mines", dropped down and raced towards him.Members of the British UFO Research Association National Conference with Robert Taylor at the site he saw a UFO near Livingston, West Lothian, in Taylor claimed to have experienced an acrid smell and the sensation of being dragged. He lost consciousness.When Taylor awoke, disorientated and with a throbbing headache, the objects were gone.His trousers were ripped in peculiar fashion, and there were grazes on his legs and chin.Robert Taylor witnessed a huge flying dome near Dechmont Law in West Lothian on November , Police who accompanied Taylor back to the site found "ladder-shaped marks" in the soil where the craft was said to have hovered, and further marks following the path of the mine-like objects.While it would later be suggested that he had suffered an epileptic seizure, mini-stroke or hallucinated after ingesting deadly nightshade berries, Taylor, who died in , never sought publicity or financial gain ndash and always stood by every word of his account.The case remains unique in British history as the only example of a UFO sighting becoming the subject of a criminal investigation.The Falkirk Triangle: Scotlands UFO capitalThe phenomenon known as the "Falkirk Triangle" ndash which includes Bonnybridge and Camelon ndash first began to gain attention in  with the area laying claim to around  sightings a year.A family out for a walk on a March evening in  spoke of witnessing a basketball-sized blue light hovering on the back road from Hallglen to Bonnybridge and claimed to hear a sound similar to a "door opening" followed by a "howl" .A video of an orange oval light above Falkirk, changing shape to becoming a white disc ndash the classic "flying saucer" shape ndash then disappearing suddenly was captured in October . The clip went viral worldwide.Billy Buchanan photographed in UFO hotspot Bonnybridge. Picture: Gordon Terris The HeraldReported sightings became so prolic that councillor Billy Buchanan, now the Falkirk provost, has lobbied three prime ministers ndash David Cameron, Tony Blair and John Major ndash over the years, asking that an investigation be launched .While many of the eerie accounts ndash which range from seeing "big, black and cigar-shaped" objects to "a bright light criss-crossed by stripes of dferent colours" ndash are thought to be misidentications caused by planes, satellites, weather balloons or planets, some simply cant be explained.One theory posited by ufologists is that the Falkirk Triangle could contain a window into another dimension, other worlds, the past or the future. We will leave you to draw your own conclusions.Blairgowrie: Scotlands earliest UFO A bizarre incident in Perthshire was reported in the Annual Register of . It described a pyramid-shaped object over the River Ericht that moved "with great speed and disappeared a little above Blairgowrie", leaving a trail of destruction that included a partly destroyed house and bridge.The area surrounding the town is said to be another hotbed of UFO activity, with reports of strange balls of light in the sky and the location of Scotlands first ever crop circle in .Blairgowrie couple Sid and Gwen Freeman experienced a series of unsettling encounters during April , including a UFO hovering over their garden and a visit from  men dressed in black.Glasgow: Floating entities and a flying railway carriageIn the west end of Glasgow two curious incidents ndash  years apart ndash were reported within the same, small geographic area. The first, in , was at Belhaven Terrace where children playing outside were terried by several entities floating above the ground dressed in long white clothes.In nearby Westbourne Gardens, in , a resident said he watched a silver disc-shaped object move towards his flat window and hover ft above the ground. Witnesses in two nearby flats corroborated his account of events." alt"East Lothian Courier: Have you spotted a UFO over Scotland  Get in touch! " class"editor-image"Have you spotted a UFO over Scotland  Get in touch! Across the city, a man waiting at a bus stop on Menock Road saw what he claimed looked like a railway carriage-shaped object passing ft above his head.The incident took place in December , with the witness reporting being able to see three windows at the front and a glimpse of swirling yellow smoke inside. Afterwards, he described a sensation of time standing still while watching it.Prestwick airport: An unexplained radar blipA series of files released by the Ministry of Defence in  revealed details of what has been dubbed the "Prestwick Airport incident", where an air traffic controller tracked a fast-moving and unexplained flying object on radar.The event, recorded in February , sparked an extensive investigation by RAF air defence staff who impounded radar tapes. However, a report concluded that no additional evidence could be found to corroborate what the air traffic controller had spotted.In August , a member of the public in West Kilbride wrote to the Ministry of Defence to report an a "fluorescent green UFO, saucer shaped" that was "harassing" a plane near Prestwick Airport.Have you spotted a UFO  Get in touchThe A Abduction: Missing hoursTravelling along the A near Harperrig Reservoir in West Lothian on August , , Garry Wood and Colin Wright saw a two-tiered, disc-shaped object above the road.According to their testimony, Wood put his foot down on the accelerator and as they passed beneath the UFO, it appeared to emit a "curtain of white light". The car began shuddering and they emerged to find themselves driving on the wrong side of the road.When Wood and Wright arrived in the South Lanarkshire village of Tarbrax, where they were due to drop off a satellite TV system, they discovered that several hours were unaccounted for. Afterwards they underwent hypnosis sessions, with both men recalling an alien abduction scenario and being subjected to a medical-type examination.Dunfermline: Anglers unexpected catchA metallic disc-shaped craft was caught on camera as it hovered above Craigluscar Reservoir near Dunfermline, Fe, on February , .Ian Macpherson, a member of the local angling club and a keen artist, was taking photographs to assist with a painting he was working on. He was first alerted to something out of the ordinary by a humming noise, similar to that from high voltage power lines.Macpherson describes a sudden uneasy feeling as he turned towards the water to see the object coming towards him. He stood frozen, watching it for more than  minutes.According to his statement: "The craft came close enough for me to see that it was definitely metallic and had several points of dfused light on its underside, inside a darker coloured rim."It was only as the disc flew off at high speed that Macpherson felt able to raise his camera and take two photographs. He said: "The crafts acceleration was phenomenal ndash by the time Id wound the film on between the two shots, it was a mere dot in the sky."By his own admission, Macpherson had no interest in the subject of UFOs. Subsequent checks with the RAF, airports and the police, confirmed no known air traffic at the time.

title: 12-natural-wonders-scotland-must-visit-lifetime
story: Narrowing down a list of favourites was no easy task, but wersquove given it a bash, bringing together a mix of well-known spots and lesser-visited gems deserving of more column inches.If you are heading out to explore this weekend, herersquos some mesmerising and memorable locations courtesy of Mother Nature.Here are  natural wonders of Scotland:Eshaness, ShetlandYou can feel the raw power of nature pulsating from what has been described as one of the most high energy coastlines in the world. Battered by the colossal force of the North Atlantic, this corner of Shetland is home to caves, stacks, arches, blowholes and geos .The peninsula is formed from the remains of the extinct Eshaness volcano, dating back some  to  million years. The clfs you see today cut through the flank of the volcano, revealing layers of lava and pyroclastic rock blasted from its crater.Visit shetland.orgAn Lochan Uaine, Glenmore, near AviemoreThe emerald waters of An Lochan Uaine, aka The Green Lochan, in Glenmore Forest Park are an enchanting sight to behold. According to legend, the distinctive hue came about when pixies washed their clothes here.Scientic bods will tell you itrsquos more likely down to the algae generated by decomposing wood that lines the lochanrsquos floor or a fluke of the light reflecting off the trees around its edges. Pah, spoilsports. I mean, who do you believe  Keep your eyes peeled for pixies on the gentle walk through the ancient Caledonian pines.Visit forestryandland.gov.scotFingalrsquos Cave, StaffaThis mysterious sea cave on the uninhabited Hebridean island of Staffa looks intricately hand-carved rather than formed by a quirk of cooling lava. The ftcavern has tremendous acoustics.Fingalrsquos Cave gained its moniker from the eponymous hero of a poem by the th-century Scots poet-historian James Macpherson .Composer Felix Mendelssohn wrote an overture in its honour, artist J M W Turner has painted it and author Jules Verne mentions it in three novels, including the famed Journey to the Centre of the Earth.Visit staffatoursBow Fiddle Rock, near Portknockie, MorayTherersquos no big secret to how this incredible natural formation got its name: it looks uncannily like a bow perched atop the strings of a fiddle. Located just off the coast from Portknockie, the distinctive shape was forged over time as the force of the waves eroded a type of rock called Cullen Quartzite.It is a place that you can photograph a hundred times and each one captures something slightly dferent ndash be it the colour of the sky, the swell of the sea or a hint of brooding atmosphere. Bow Fiddle Rock forms part of the North East  route as it traverses the Moray Firth coastline.Visit northeast and visitscotlandFortingall Yew, PerthshireThe Fortingall Yew, pictured, found growing in the churchyard of the Perthshire village which shares its name, is among the oldest trees in Europe. There is some debate about its age. Modern experts estimate the tree is between , and , years old.Fortingall YewAccording to folklore, Pontius Pilate ndash the Roman governor who oversaw the crucixion of Jesus ndash was born in its shade and played there as a child. More recently this legend has been credited as a hoax devised by Sir Donald Currie, a shipping magnate who bought the Glenlyon Estate in .Visit visitscotlandOrkneyrsquos sea stacksThe rugged clfs and coastline around Orkney boast a raft of spectacular sea stacks with The Old Man of Hoy, a fthigh monolith of towering, red sandstone perhaps its most famous. That said, he it has many handsome siblings, such as The Needle on Hoyrsquos south-west coast.The Old Man of Hoy. Picture: Cameron McNeish Scottish Walks MagazineTherersquos the striking Yesnaby Castle on the west mainland, and North Gaulton Castle which the eagle-eyed may recognise from a  car advert for Rover. Further up the mainland coast, just north of the Bay of Skaill, therersquos the brilliantly named Stack orsquo Roo.Visit orkneyGalloway Forest Dark Sky Park, Dumfries and GallowayWhen did you last see the Milky Way  For those of us residing in urban areas, itrsquos more likely we are familiar with the sweet treat found in corner shops than the bright band arching across the night sky. Galloway Forest Park is a perfect spot to go stargazing.Very few people live within its  square miles area which means the nights are jet black. A clutch of planets and more than , twinkling stars are visible with the naked eye. The Perseid meteor shower reaches its peak from August  to  this year. Top tip: take a sun lounger because it saves on neck craning.Visit scottishdarkskyobservatory and forestryandland.gov.scotThe Cuillin, SkyeRed or black  Itrsquos almost impossible to choose, like being asked to pick a favourite child. The Cuillin is made up of two ranges ndash the Black Cuillin and the Red Cuillin ndash separated by Glen Sligachan.They were formed by volcanic and glacial activity, then further sculpted by weathering over the millennia to emerge looking very dferent indeed.The jagged outlines of the Black Cuillin are the remains of a magma chamber belonging to a giant volcano and comprised largely of rough gabbro rock, while the rounded humps of the Red Cuillin are made mainly of granite.Visit visitscotlandCorryvreckan Whirlpool, ArgyllA perilous, swirling vortex with a formidable reputation. The Corryvreckan Whirlpool, between Jura and Scarba, is infamous for strong tidal currents and standing waves that make it one of the most dangerous stretches within the British Isles. At times, the mighty roar is so loud that it can be heard  miles away. The whirlpool is the third-largest in the world and caused by an unusual underwater topography in the Gulf of Corryvreckan that creates the so-called speckled cauldron. There are boat tours available for those brave enough to venture here.Visit craignishcruises and juraboattoursGrey Marersquos Tail, Moffat, DumfriesshireTalk about a beautul image. Evenyou have never seen this thundering waterfall in the flesh, you can imagine what it looks like ndash the swishing grey tail of a mare ndash as it cascades down ftwhere the Tail Burn flows from Loch Skeen into the Moffat Water Valley.Grey Mares Tail. Picture: National Trust for ScotlandIts majesty was celebrated in verse by Sir Walter Scott who wrote in Marmion about the frothing water as being as ldquowhite as the snowy chargerrsquos tail. There is historical evidence in the nearby area of Iron Age settlers and the Covenanters who sought sanctuary in the th century.Visit nts.org.ukBass Rock, East LothianSure, itrsquos a big lump of rock covered in bird poo, but, in geological and natural history terms, the Bass Rock is a stunner. The steep-sided volcanic plug rises ftout of the Firth of Forth.It is regarded as a Site of Special Scientic Interest and is renowned for its vast gannet colony ndash some , at the peak of the breeding season ndash hailed by Sir David Attenborough as ldquoone of the  wildle wonders of the world.The Bass Rock has been a retreat for early Christian hermits, welcomed royal visits and served as a notorious gaol for religious and political prisoners.Visit seabird.orgThe beaches of Sanday, OrkneySanday by name, sandy by nature. Seen from the air you would be forgiven for imagining you had flown through a tear in the space-time continuum and were seeing a tropical island in the Caribbean or South Pacic rather than Scotland. Bays and beaches, white sands and turquoise waters abound.Among the many gems on Sanday is Tresness, a sliver of a peninsula with ine dunes sandwiched between a sheltered tidal bay to the west and the North Sea on the east. Therersquos also the gorgeous Whitemill Bay, Lopness, Sty Wick, Scuthvie Bay and Sandquoy ndash the list goes on.Visit orkney

title: lengthy-wait-gyms-swimming-pools-reopen-doors
story: The Scottish Government announced plans to relax coronavirus-related restrictions, which could see indoor sports facilities, including swimming pools, open their doors again on September .Enjoyleisure, which operates sports centres in Dunbar, Haddington, Musselburgh, North Berwick and Tranent, says it has already made ldquosignicant progress in preparing the facilities for reopening.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which employs  people, including relief colleagues, said it had been a dficult time, with sports centres having been closed for almost six months by the time they could reopen.A revenue shortfall of about pound. million is being predicted for this financial year, with  members of staff currently furloughed, with a number of others taken off furlough prior to the reopening of golf courses and outdoor pitch facilities.Mr Axon said: ldquoAs the local leisure charitable trust provider, we deliver essential services at an affordable and subsidised cost for all.ldquoWe dynamically contribute to the local economy, whilst generating social value across communities on account of improved personal and collective health, wellbeing, social cohesion, and decreased antisocial behaviour and crime.ldquoOur role will be even more important as we begin to recover as a community from the after effects of lockdown.ldquoLike other providers within the public charitable sector, enjoy has had many financial challenges to overcome over the years, which has not been easy.ldquoHowever due to pragmatic and sound decision making, with support from my board, staff and trade unions, enjoy has maintained a stable financial position.ldquoSince the Covid- lockdown on March , enjoyleisurersquos income levels have become non-existent.ldquoThe charity is currently predicting a revenue shortfall of circa pound. million for  .ldquoHowever, we have taken signicant actions that have gone some way to mitigating these losses.Measures are currently being put into place at sports centres ahead of the reopening date in a bid to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.Enjoyleisure said it was ldquocompletely redefining its cleaning and safety standards, while risk assessments are being updated.Physical distancing measures are also being introduced, including one-way systems, dedicated two-metre square workout areas within gyms and fitness studios while the number of lockers and changing cubicles available will also be reduced.New booking procedures will be introduced while staff will be retrained in the new safety and hygiene protocols and will be supplied with their own PPE.Mr Axon said they would need support to get back to ldquoa position of strength while requests have been made to the Government for emergency funding.He added: ldquoI am delighted that both Iain Gray MSP and Kenny MacAskill MP have provided their backing for enjoyrsquos request, as they acknowledge the real and substantial sporting, health, personal and collective wellbeing benefits from having a thriving, motivated and community supporting leisure trust within East Lothian.ldquoI have full confidence in enjoyrsquos ability to continue safely serving our communities, and provide the vital amenities, quality facilities and activities truly lsquoenjoyedrsquo by our patrons.ldquoI and everyone connected with enjoy are totally committed to maintaining these high standards for everyone who resides or visits East Lothian.Enjoyleisure also confirmed the summer seasonal facilities would not be reopening until .A spokeswoman for the group said: ldquoIn terms of the summer seasonal facilities, North Berwick putting greens, Fisherrow bowling green and pitch n putt these facilities will regrettably not be opening this year.ldquoDue to the nature of the pandemic and timescales provided, it would not have been financially viable to open these facilities this year.

title: welcome-return-beach-wheelchairs-restarts-north-berwick
story: The charity offers specially designed wheelchairs that allow people with disabilities or those who need to use a wheelchair the chance to enjoy East Lothianrsquos beaches.It temporarily closed its hut on March  in line with Government guidance at the time as the coronavirus lockdown got under way.An all-terrain power wheelchair, four manual wheelchairs, a beach walker and a hoist are on offer from the charity.All equipment is free to hire but those who wish to use the service are asked to book in advance by calling   , with volunteers then discussing what best suits an inidualrsquos needs.Beach Wheelchairs is following strict health and safety guidelines to keep its volunteers and customers safe.All equipment will be thoroughly cleaned between each use and each wheelchair will be left for at least  hours between each use.Volunteers will all be wearing masks and gloves.The power wheelchair will only be available to those who have used it previously this is because social distancing means providing safety training will be dficult to do from a two-metre distance.When using the hoist, people are asked to bring their own sling.People will have to move and store the wheelchair they hire themselves without the assistance of a volunteer and they are recommended to use the wheelchairs service at quieter times.It is recommended that two carers are in attendance unless people are confident that one carer can help with no physical assistance from a volunteer.Those who begin to experience symptoms of coronavirus after using one of the beach wheelchairs are asked to let volunteers know as soon as possible so that the chair can be removed from service for  hours.For more information, visit Beach Wheelchairs on Facebook.

title: ready-take-off-museum-flight-reopens-doors
story: Visitors to the museum ndash which closed in March due to the coronavirus lockdown ndash need to book a time slot in advance. Tickets are available online.Until next Sunday , the museum will be free to enter.Concorde and the museumrsquos shop will open first, with hangars two and three reopening from next Monday .Several new measures have been introduced to ensure visitors have a safe visit.People are encouraged to keep a two-metre distance from others, use the hand sanitiser on-site, wash their hands, follow direction signs and pay for items using a card.Visitors are also asked to wear face coverings in indoor spaces and shops.National Museums Scotland also confirmed that two of its other venues are scheduled to reopen, the Museum of Rural Le on Wednesday and National Museum of Scotland on August . title: musselburgh-rugby-club-beer-garden-offers-safe-place
story: Members and guests were welcomed to the large outdoor space which has been created at its grounds at Stoneyhill.The beer garden and lsquoPickerings Patiorsquo ndash named after one of the clubrsquos main sponsors Pickerings Gin ndash is offering them a safe space to visit as the lockdown eases.A club spokesperson said: ldquoWe hope it will be a welcome facility for the local community and a permanent feature as the club moves into its centenary year in .ldquoThe club has done a lot of work getting familiar with all of the Covid government and council guidance, including full risk assessments and ensuring all staff have appropriate PPE.ldquoWe have installed sanitisers at key posts around the club and have an increased cleaning system for our toilet and bar facilities, as well as introducing systems in the bar and toilets which implement social distancing.The spokesperson added: ldquoWe really enjoyed welcoming back members and guests to our new outdoor space which we have worked hard to make sure is a safe area, given we have the luxury to use a lot of space outside the club.ldquoWe recognise peoplersquos levels of comfort will be very dferent coming outof lockdown and want to ensure we offer a safe place to visit, while also offering some form of normality, as the club has always been a welcoming and fun place to visit.ldquoThe staff have been doing a great job and we recognise it is still a learning curve for everyone, including guests.ldquoWe are looking to adapt to opening insidewe have to address any poor weather but this brings restrictions and will be thought out in more detail moving forward.The beer garden and Pickerings Patio is open Fridays pm-pm, Saturdays noon-pm and Sundays pm-pm.While walk-ins are welcome, subject to availability, bookings are recommended at the Eventbrite link via www.musselburghrfc

title: schools-planning-soft-start-new-term
story: Pupils across the county face changes as theyto school with increased emphasis on hand hygiene, staggered breaks and lunch times and no assemblies or even indoor PE initially.And they will be told to wear face masks on all home to school transport after East Lothian Council took the decision to introduce the rule across the board with exceptions for additional support learning pupils and those with medical exemptions.Primary school staff are writing to parents outlining changes to the school day which will see them asked to say goodbye to their children at school gates and youngsters barred from playing or mixing with friends in other classes initially, as they are kept in class clusters.While youngsters are not expected to social distance in schools, teaching staff will have to maintain a safe distance. In primary schools, changes include children being kept in their own class group during break times and lunch times instead of being allowed to mix with other youngsters, staggered starts and requests for parents of older children P- not to come into the playground with them in the mornings but to remain at school gates.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the youngstersrsquoto schools with a special thought for those starting school for the first time.He said: ldquoTheof pupils to school is the biggest, and most important move out of lockdown yet.ldquoGood luck to all of the countyrsquos pupils and teachers as they finally get back to face to face learning.ldquoAs a grandad with two grandchildren starting school for the first time, I am thinking especially of those new P pupils.ldquoI know that teachers, cleaners, janitors, classroom assistants and our local education department have worked incredibly hard for this day, to ensure that schools can restart safely.ldquoThey were not helped by the government telling them to plan for social distancing in the classroom, and then suddenly being told thewould be full time ndash but I have every confidence that they will have turned that round.ldquoI know that many parents will have mixed feelings, pleased that their children are going back to school, because home schooling has been tough for all families, but anxious for their childrenrsquos safety too.ldquoIt is important that everything needed is in place ndash sanitiser, testing, and, in senior years social distancing where possible.
