story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs reported in the Penarth Times on Thursday, the town councilsaid the results show ldquowidespread backing for changes.The survey, which attracted  responses, showed  per cent of people thought there should be more outdoor space for pedestrians and businesses.Seventy-five per cent thought parking arrangements needed to change, and  per cent said the town needs to ldquoprepare for the future.Some traders, who oppose the changes ndash specically a one-way traffic system around the town and making Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street a traffic free zone, have said the questions in the survey were too generalised and misleading.As a result of the survey, Penarth Town Council have proposed the following changes to the original ideas:Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and buses, with a mph speed limit.Lower Glebe Street as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and disabled bays. Other vehicles should not use Lower Glebe Street as a through road.Bus stops will remain as they are. There were concerns over the impact of a bus stop on Hickman Road for traders, due to air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.A two-way system to remain on Stanwell Road from the library to the traffic lights, to allow easy access to the bus stop on Rectory Road and to prevent congestion and ldquorat running through Hickman Road and Arcot Street. A two-way system to also remain from Windsor Road to Railway Terrace.The number of parking bays has also changed. There will now be  extra bays proposed, with  of them on Plassey Street.The leader of the town council, Cllr Rhiannon Birch, explained the findings and what happens next.ldquoEven before Covid-, town centres across the country were facing issues, including the need to modernise infrastructure, and the impact of online shopping, she said. ldquoThe current pandemic has added to the scale of the challenge.ldquoThe consultation shows that a clear majority recognise the need for a degree of change in the town centre, both for it to survive in the present and to thrive in future.ldquoThe results call for the establishment of a greater degree of safe space and proposals which increase a degree of pedestrianisation whilst also increasing parking spaces.ldquoThe results show substantial agreement on these aims. Reflecting this widespread and clear response, Penarth Town Council calls on our partners in the Vale of Glamorgan Council to embrace the results and recommendations.ldquoSpecically, Penarth Town Council believes that creating a safer environment through the closure of Windsor Road to traffic for part of the day, between Arcot Street and the roundabout, including the Lower Glebe Street, would be the best way to ensure that people can feel confident about shopping safely. It would allow safe use of the space in front of shops, bars, cafes and restaurants.ldquoIt also lessens the need for one-way systems on pavements for pedestrians, which are perplexing for many and hard to implement. These proposals can be achieved in a way which also increases the amount of parking spaces available.The results will now be put to the Vales Planning Committee for consultation.For more information, visit https:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk news survey-results Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. click-and-collect service was launched in late June.That allows members to borrow books, audiobooks and DVDs on an appointment basis and even submit preference requests relating to authors or genres.Now residents will be able to access further facilities as the use of PCs and the physical browsing of books is permitted again.Initially, PCs can be booked for a -minute period once a week, with the number available reduced to allow for appropriate social distancing.Fixed time limits will also mean staff can properly sanitise machines between uses.MORE STORIESVale of Glamorgan libraries offer click and collect serviceBarry library closes in wake of coronavirus concernsVale Libraries lockdown Lit Facebook group established for book-loversIt will also be possible to secure a -minute slot to browse and select books from the libraries, with strict restrictions on the number of people admitted to the buildings at any one time.Library members can make appointments for either of these services by phone.Vale council cabinet member for education and regeneration, Cllr Lis Burnett said: ldquoWe know what a vital role our libraries play in the lives of some of our residents, especially at a time when most are spending more time at home.ldquoReading in particular is a productive and stimulating way to fill time so Irsquom delighted that we are now able to make more of our library services available again.ldquoWhile increasing numbers of people have been accessing books, resources and activities online, for many the reopening of library buildings will be very welcomelsquoOur library staff have worked hard to provide as many facilities as possible online, but I know they are looking forward to seeing familiar faces and hopefully some new ones too.ldquoResidents will be able to use PCs and visit libraries in person to browse books though both activities will be tightly controlled.ldquoSafety remains the number one priority and all appropriate measures will be in place to protect both library members and staff.During this period, chairs will be removed from the libraries to discourage sitting, toilets will be closed to the public and there will be no meetings, activities or room bookings available.Anyone entering the building will be asked to use hand gel and complete a track and trace card giving their name and contact details.Library staff will work behind protective screens when at a desk and wear visors at other times and all books will be quarantined for  hours before being cleaned and put back into circulation.Current weekday opening times will remain the same initially, with Barry and Cowbridge operating from am to pm and pm to pm, and Llantwit Major open for the second of those periods.The Libraries will also open between am and pm on Saturdays.As building improvement work is shortly due to take place at Penarth Library, that will not open in the same way as the councilrsquos other libraries.However, it will continue to offer a phone and internet click-and-collect service, as will Barry, Cowbridge and Llantwit Major.Community libraries in Rhoose, St Athan and Sully are also offering a click-and-collect service, with Dinas Powys and Wenvoe likely to join them in the near future.Some other council services will also be available face to face at the Civic Offices on an appointment basis from Monday, August .Appointments can now be made for registrars, council tax and benefits services by telephone.More details can be found at www.valeofglamorgan.gov.ukGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and UK-wide day of action highlighting the urgent government help the sector needs during the covid- crisis.The live events industry across the UK will come together, at pm on Tuesday, August  to host a series of creative action to help save the live events and entertainment sector which is on the verge of collapsing without financial support from the government.Hundreds of venues are expected to to turning red are the Motorpoint Arena, Cardf Castle, Principality Stadium, City Hall, Wales Millennium Centre, New Theatre, Chapter, St Davidrsquos Hall, venues in Womanby Street, USW Atrium, Dolman Theatre, ICC Wales.Sarah Hemsley-Cole, director of SC Productions Ltd, an events production company based in Cardf said: ldquoCovid- has had a devastating effect on the live events and arts sector here in Wales, not only our theatres, but our touring shows, stadium shows, live music venues and outdoor arts have been decimated by the pandemic.ldquoThe ecosystem of our creative industry ndash skilled professional such as technicians, designers, actors, performers, musicians and suppliers are now fighting for survival."In Wales alone there are in excess of  iniduals employed within the creative industries, and with the governments furlough scheme ending in October, and with no sense of a time line when events and venues can re-open ndash many are being forced in to poverty debt and despondency.ldquoWith no timeline or criteria having been issued by the Welsh Government for their administration of the cultural recovery fund, unlike the Welsh Arts Council who have released their timeline for applications, this delay will leave the whole industry extremely vulnerable and at risk of extinction.ldquoWe urgently need the financial support across the creative industries extended, we need support now in order to support anyone and everyone from falling through the cracks, and we need grants not loans for the supply chain.ldquoAll live events, including sporting events, provide both a massive part of many peoplersquos social calendar and a huge amount of employment.ldquoThe call to action hopes to raise awareness for over a million professionals at risk of losing their jobs, , of whom deliver outdoor events, around  per cent of the workforce are freelance.ldquoThe imminent closure of the self-employed income support scheme at the end of the month threatens their livelihood.ldquoUnlike other industries, events, festivals, and performances have been unable to safely reopen due to social distancing guidance and may not reopen until early  ndash and opening times keep being pushed back.ldquoWith no government support on the horizon for the event supply chain, redundancies have already begun, research indicates that  per cent of companies will have served redundancy notices by end of August, this rises to  per cent by the end of December.Cardf Motorpoint Arena managing director, Phil Sheeran added: ldquoThis isnrsquot just about our venues and the staff specically associated with them.ldquoNor just about the companies directly involved in live events.ldquoThis is also about the hotels and their staff where fans stay pre and post concerts.ldquoRestaurants, bars and pubs where for lots of concert goers the evening begins.ldquoTaxis, bus companies, trains and even airlines.ldquoProbably every business in a city like Cardf benefits in some way or another from the economic impact of the live events industry at whatever venue size you can think of.ldquoThe risk is huge for many, many people and sectors.ldquoWe need to get back to work without restrictions.ldquoIf that cannot happen then the support mechanisms like furlough, grants ndash not loans, and an extension to the self-employment scheme must be continued.More professional such as technicians, designers, actors, performers, musicians and suppliers are now fighting for survival."In Wales alone there are in excess of  iniduals employed within the creative industries, and with the governments furlough scheme ending in October, and with no sense of a time line when events and venues can re-open ndash many are being forced in to poverty debt and despondency.ldquoWith no timeline or criteria having been issued by the Welsh Government for their administration of the cultural recovery fund, unlike the Welsh Arts Council who have released their timeline for applications, this delay will leave the whole industry extremely vulnerable and at risk of extinction.ldquoWe urgently need the financial support across the creative industries extended, we need support now in order to support anyone and everyone from falling through the cracks, and we need grants not loans for the supply chain.ldquoAll live events, including sporting events, provide both a massive part of many peoplersquos social calendar and a huge amount of employment.ldquoThe call to action hopes to raise awareness for over a million professionals at risk of losing their jobs, , of whom deliver outdoor events, around  per cent of the workforce are freelance.ldquoThe imminent closure of the self-employed income support scheme at the end of the month threatens their livelihood.ldquoUnlike other industries, events, festivals, and performances have been unable to safely reopen due to social distancing guidance and may not reopen until early  ndash and opening times keep being pushed back.ldquoWith no government support on the horizon for the event supply chain, redundancies have already begun, research indicates that  per cent of companies will have served redundancy notices by end of August, this rises to  per cent by the end of December.Cardf Motorpoint Arena managing director, Phil Sheeran added: ldquoThis isnrsquot just about our venues and the staff specically associated with them.ldquoNor just about the companies directly involved in live events.ldquoThis is also about the hotels and their staff where fans stay pre and post concerts.ldquoRestaurants, bars and pubs where for lots of concert goers the evening begins.ldquoTaxis, bus companies, trains and even airlines.ldquoProbably every business in a city like Cardf benefits in some way or another from the economic impact of the live events industry at whatever venue size you can think of.ldquoThe risk is huge for many, many people and sectors.ldquoWe need to get back to work without restrictions.ldquoIf that cannot happen then the support mechanisms like furlough, grants ndash not loans, and an extension to the self-employment scheme must be continued.More title: new species dinosaur discovered isle wight
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPalaeontologists from the University of Southampton say the creature lived in the Cretaceous period  million years ago and is estimated to have been up to four metres long.The dinosaur ndash which is a new species of theropod dinosaur, the group that includes Tyrannosaurus rex and modern-day birds ndash has been named Vectaerovenator inopinatus.The name refers to the large air spaces in some of the bones, one of the traits that helped the scientists identy its theropod origins.These air sacs, also seen in modern birds, were extensions of the lungs.It is likely they helped fuel an efficient breathing system while also making the skeleton lighter.The bones, discovered on the foreshore at Shanklin last year, are from the neck, back and tail. vw,vw,px, px"Still images of the vertebrae The fossils were found over a period of weeks in  in three separate discoveries ndashtwo by iniduals and one by a family group, who all handed in their finds to the nearby Dinosaur Isle Museum at Sandown.Scientic study has confirmed the fossils are very likely to be from the same inidual dinosaur, with the exact location and timing of the finds adding to this belief.Robin Ward, a regular fossil hunter from Stratford-upon-Avon, was with his family visiting the Isle of Wight when they made their discovery.He said: ldquoThe joy of finding the bones we discovered was absolutely fantastic. I thought they were special and so took them along when we visited Dinosaur Isle Museum.ldquoThey immediately knew these were something rare and askedwe could donate them to the museum to be fully researched.James Lockyer, from Spalding, Lincolnshire was also visiting the island when he found another of the bones.He said: ldquoIt looked dferent from marine reptile vertebrae I have come across in the past.ldquoI was searching a spot at Shanklin and had been told and read that I wouldnrsquot find much there.ldquoHowever, I always make sure I search the areas others do not, and on this occasion it paid off.After studying the four vertebrae, palaeontologists from the University of Southampton confirmed that the bones are likely to belong to a genus of dinosaur previously unknown to science.Their findings will be published in the journal Papers In Palaeontology.Chris Barker, a PhD student at the university who led the study, said: ldquoWe were struck by just how hollow this animal was ndash itrsquos riddled with air spaces.ldquoParts of its skeleton must have been rather delicate.ldquoThe record of theropod dinosaurs from the lsquomidrsquo Cretaceous period in Europe isnrsquot that great, so itrsquos been really exciting to be able to increase our understanding of the ersity of dinosaur species from this time.ldquoYou donrsquot usually find dinosaurs in the deposits at Shanklin as they were laid down in a marine habitat.ldquoYoursquore much more likely to find fossil oysters or drtwood, so this is a rare find indeed.Scientists say that it is likely the Vectaerovenator lived in an area just north of where its remains were found, with the carcass having washed out into the shallow sea nearby..push,i[r].l*new title: a level students can use grades mock exams progress degree courses
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityResults in mock tests ndash which were held before schools were forced to close amid the Covid- crisis ndash will carry the same weight as the calculated results to be awarded this month, Gavin Williamson said.The move, described by one union leader as ldquopanicked and chaotic, comes after unions called on the UK Government to follow Scotlandrsquos lead in scrapping moderated grades as the downgrading of more than , results was reversed.In a U-turn announced on Tuesday, Scotlandrsquos Education Secretary John Swinney revealed that downgraded results would revert to the grades estimated by pupilsrsquo teachers.It comes after this yearrsquos summer exams were cancelled amid Covid-. Teachers were told to submit the grades they thought each student would have receivedthey had sat the papers.Exam boards have moderated these grades to ensure this yearrsquos results ndash for students in England, Northern Ireland and Wales ndash are not signicantly higher than previous years.But now students in England awaiting their A-level and GCSE results can keep their grades in mock examsthey are higher than the calculated grade, with regulator Ofqual asked to determine how and when valid mock results can be used.Students will have to go through the appeals process to use their mock exam result, with their school required to submit evidence to the exam board.And they will still be able to sit exams in the autumnthey are unhappy with the grades they secured in mock exams, orthey are dissatisfied with results awarded by exam boards on Thursday.All three grades will hold the same value with universities, colleges and employers, the Department for Educationsaid. vw,vw,px, px"Secretary of State for Education Gavin Williamson Mr Williamson also announced an additional pound million in funding to help schools and colleges carry out the autumn exam series for students wishing to sit GCSE and A-level exams.But the appeals process ndash where inidual students in England are dependent on schools and colleges to appeal against results on their behalf ndash is expected to remain the same.Mr Williamson said: ldquoEvery young person waiting for their results wants to know they have been treated fairly.ldquoBy ensuring students have the safety net of their mock results, as well as the chance of sitting autumn exams, we are creating a triple lock process to ensure they can have the confidence to take the next step forward in work or education.Geoff Barton, General Secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said the plan created potential for ldquomassive inconsistency as mock exams were not standardised and some students may not have taken them before schools closed in March.He said: ldquoThe idea of introducing at the eleventh hour a system in which mock exam results trump calculated grades beggars belief. The government doesnrsquot appear to understand how mock exams work. They arenrsquot a set of exams which all conform to the same standards. The clue is in the name lsquomockrsquo.ldquoSchools and colleges have spent months diligently following detailed guidance to produce centre-assessed grades only to find they might as well not have bothered.ldquoIf the government wanted to change the system it should have spent at least a few days discussing the options rather than rushing out a panicked and chaotic response. vw,vw,px, px"Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer: lsquoI would urge the Prime Minister to change course, or he risks robbing a generation of their futurersquo Labour has urged the Government to carry out urgent changes, including helping students to correct their grades with credible appeals and resits and clarying which students are likely to be worst affected by the model being used.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: ldquoWith  hours before results are released, I would urge the Prime Minister to change course, or he risks robbing a generation of their future.Lord Baker, who served as an education secretary under Margaret Thatcher, said it appeared Scotland had ldquogot it right and those that will suffer from downgrading are most likely to be the brightest students in the poorest schools.He told the : ldquoScotland makes it exceptionally dficult for the Prime Minister. Itrsquos egg on face, there is no question about that.There are also fears mid-ranking A-level students could face a grading ldquolottery after they were put in rank order against their classmates within each grade for each subject, according to Professor Alan Smithers, director of the Centre for Education and Employment Research at the University of Buckingham..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: A-level students can use grades in mock exams to progress to degree courses article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: traffic disruption expected two psk ni road schemes start
story: Restaurant which provides employment for young people with special needs closes its doorsTraffic disruption expected as two £k NI road schemes to startNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsTraffic disruption expected as two £k NI road schemes to startTwo £k resurfacing schemes for parts of Co Armagh are start this week with traffic disruptions expected.By Carmel RobinsonTuesday, th August , : am""The schems include two contracts, one in Mowhan Road, Markethill costing £k and another in Laurelvale, Tandragee costing £k.Newry and Armagh DUP MLA William Irwin and Independent Cllr Paul Berry both welcomed the schemes.Mr Irwin said, “This is fantastic news for road users and residents of Markethill and the surrounding area and I understand that work is due to commence on Mowhan Road Markethill on Monday  August  with the work extending  kilometres from its junction with the Cladymilltown Road to just south of the Tullyallen Road junction.”Paul BerryHe added. “Access for residents will be maintained at all times however it will be closed to through traffic from th August to th September between the hours of am and pm Monday – Friday and ersions will be signposted. Officials state that the road will be open to traffic in the evenings during the week and all day on Saturday and Sunday.”He added, “It is also great to see work commencing in Laurelvale and Mullavilly with an investment of close to £,. A closure scheme in a similar manner will see the road closed from Monday  August to Friday  September between the hours of .am and .pm and access maintained for residents throughout the works phase and the roads will be open outside of construction hours.”He added, “When both sets of works are combined this represents a signicant investment locally in the constituency. The roads in question will certainly benefit from this work and in both instances the surfaces have been slowly deteriorating over time.”“Whilst there will be iniably disruption to traffic flow during the works, it will be a worthwhile scheme to ensure that the road surfaces in both locations are maintained to the standards expected and I thank Transport NI for this investment.”William Irwin MLAMr Berry said roads in the Mullavilly Road area of Laurelvale had been in a ‘dreadful state’ for a long time.He said: “I have lobbied Infrastructure NI for few years now and kept in close contact to ensure that the main street and a section of road from the bus shelter and footpaths be resurfaced. That section of road has been in dreadful state for a long time and the water gathered along the road, so drainage is key. There is also a need to look again at the current ramps as they are in over  years now and need redesigned. Obviously there is going to be traffic disruption over the next number of weeks but long term these road improvements will be great long term for the Village.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Homeless man thanks NI town’s community for ‘kindness and support’Restaurant which provides employment for young people with special needs closes its doorsNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  .
